prompt.p: In sickle cell disease, the haemoglobin molecule is abnormal. Red cells containing sickle haemoglobin elongate under conditions of reduced oxygen tension to form the characteristic sickle shape. These cells are more readily adherent to vascular endothelium than normal red blood cells, and do not flow well through small vessels. This can lead to vascular occlusion and sickle cell crisis.
